Award.AwardTitle: Instrument Development: A Miniature, High-resolution, Stationary Grating Spatial Heterodyne UV Raman Spectrometer-Towards Miniature UV Raman Sensors and "Raman on a Chip"
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program in the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Stanley M. Angel and his students at the University of South Carolina, will develop miniature deep-UV Raman spectrometers of unprecedentedly small size. The miniature Raman spectrometer design is based on a stationary grating, spatial heterodyne spectrometer (SHS) and will have high spectral resolution, a large spectral range and high light throughput. The proposed UV Raman spectrometer is a radically new design that allows mm-size spectrometers with spectral characteristics equal to or better than larger instruments and with higher light throughput than conventional Raman instruments of comparable size, and with high acceptance angle. The proposed work is designed to move towards miniature Raman chemical sensors. The spectrometer will substantially broaden the applicability of Raman for on-line, in-situ, in-vivo, and standoff measurements, in wide-ranging applications. This project will include studies in four major areas: 1) what are the fundamental size limitations of a SHS based Raman spectrometer, 2) how do noise and background sources scale with instrument size, 3) how can an interferometer output be coupled to an external detector, and 4) what new applications are made possible by the availability of a miniature UV Raman spectrometer. The implications of on-line spectroscopic sensors to chemical process monitoring and advanced and additive manufacturing will be explored.


Raman spectrometers provide information about the molecular composition of samples by recording small changes in the wavelength (color) of incident light produced by molecular vibrations in the sample. In this project, miniature spectroscopic tools will be developed using cutting-edge technology, opening up whole new areas of analytical measurement possibilities because the small size and UV spectroscopic performance of the miniature SHRS proposed will substantially broaden the range of Raman spectrometer applications. Areas of potential use include chemical process monitoring, on-line chemical kinetics measurements, imaging of biological tissues and cells, standoff forensics analysis, planetary exploration, hand held geological instruments, deep-ocean oceanographic measurements, electronics device characterization, high explosives detection, and many others. This project also provides outstanding opportunities for undergraduates and graduate students to acquire knowledge and skills in spectroscopy, lasers and optics as well as applications of analytical chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit of the proposed activity: A new type of Fourier transform Raman spectrometer was developed and characterized with the goal of demonstrating the feasability of making miniature, mm-scale, Raman spectrometers to provide new chemical measurement capabilities. The new Raman spectrometer is based on a spatial heterodyne spectrometer (SHS) which is a relatively new type of fixed grating interferometer.  The SHS Raman (SHRS) is amenable to miniaturization because the resolution is not a strong function of aperture size, determined only by the number of grooves illuminated on the grating, and the throughput is very high for diffuse sources.  This is a new Raman capability that will facilitate a wide range of applied and basic chemical measurements by extending in situ spectroscopic sensing technology to new areas. 

A key technical outcome of this project was demonstrating an SHRS using gratings as small as 2.5 mm and showing the use of a cell-phone for this Raman spectrometer as the light collector, light detector and to display the interferogram, using a moderate laser power of 100 mW (see attached picture).  To our knowledge this is the first description of a cell-phone based Raman spectrometer in a peer-reviewed journal.  The use of an uncooled cell-phone camera was possible in large part because of the high throughput of the miniature SHRS.  Raman spectra of a variety of samples measured with the cell phone SHRS Raman spectrometer were found to be comparable to measurements made using the same miniature SHRS with high-quality imaging optics and a scientific-grade, cooled CCD. The resolution of this system was ~17-18 cm-1, limited by the cell-phone optics.  Despite the significantly higher noise and lower sensitivity of the cell phone camera sensor, the high light throughput and multiplex advantage inherent to the SHRS design allowed Raman spectra to be measured, in some cases with SNR only 2-3 times worse than using a scientific grade CCD.  

 In other studies with the SHRS we demonstrated its use for standoff Raman measurements at distances up to 20 meters and showed that the large field of view of the SHRS made alignment at long distances much easier than using a slit-based dispersive spectrometer.  Also, the SHRS was very forgiving of alignment instabilities that are sometimes a problem with remote Raman.  The throughput advantage for diffuse sources, offered by the wide field of view of the SHRS, was also demonstrated by using it to make a series of transmission Raman measurements and comparing the results to similar measurements that were made using a high throughput, f/1.8, dispersive spectrometer.  This is a significant result because transmission Raman has been shown to be very useful for measuring diffuse scattering pharmaceutical samples, but the large size of the diffuse scattered beam from the samples can be difficult to efficiently couple into the small slit of a dispersive spectrometer.  

Broader impacts of the proposed activity: The project studies produced 9 published, in press, accepted, or submitted peer-reviewed papers and more than 13 other papers presented at conferences, many invited.  Several more peer-reviewed publications are expected from ongoing work that we are just finishing.  In addition, three graduate student (one female) PhD theses and one MS were supported, in large part by this work and one current female PhD student was partially supported. Two undergraduate students, one female, have also been supported by this project. All of these students have benefited by collaborating with scientists from Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL). Dr. Carter from LLNL spent many weeks working with these students in our lab during this project.
